person.education: A Gladys Mary Stephens from Newton, MA appears in lists of "Special Students" in the Boston University Yeark Book for 1907 and 1909, but not for 1908. According to the Year Book for 1907, students could be admitted as special students if they were "taking one or more particular course of work, without being a candidate for a degree," were "deficient on prelimiary preparation," or had "not passed the full number of examinations required for admission" to the class to which they sought admission. Special students were classified in three groups, and Stephens appears in lists of the first group (Group A), "those enrolled in the College [of Liberal Arts] only" (special students in the other groups were enrolled in "Teachers' Courses" or in other departments of the University.

div.p:
I have made my
first trip to the Exposition
Grounds. They are simply
dreams of beauty. Such
flowers—and such
quantities of them! There
is one place where there
are thousands and
thousands of white,
lavender and pure yellow
pansies. In one place
there are veritable terraces
of water with a falls between
This expanse is surrounded
by the most beautiful
display of poppies I ever
saw. Then there are
flowers like those I brought
home from Senior Prom.—
gerhaniums—dwarf
sweet peas—every kind
of flowers imaginable.
Talk abut roses, there
are so many here that
I can't think what
California will be like.
I went today with
the Virginians. The men
were hunting up old
friends here in the
city. I have a lot of
truck, which I am going
to send by mail. There
are four pictures of
Yellowstone which are
exquisite—they are
as natural as pictures
can be. My Princetonian
got them for me, and
paid a dollar for
them. The packages of tea
I got at the Japanese
tea garden from the
little Japanese girl. I
ordered (through Hayden)
a 5 cent can of condense
milk.

The buildings are fine
at the fair. One of the
Virginian ladies said
this fair is much superior
to the St. Louis and others
because of its compactness
as well as its beauty.
The buildings will be
used later as college b'l'd'gsbuildings.
Today we only visited
those in the inner circle.
The place is laid out in
this way
Layout of the fairgrounds.
A freehand sketch of the layout of the fairgrounds.
The amusement street
is called pay streak—a
mining term.

The city has several
skyscrapers.

There is a Hawaiian
village with real bare
natives. We are going to
visit it later. There also
Esquimos and a village.
I am sending you
also the daily program.
Have not found the
Goulds yet.

This morning it was
raining and I slept until
3
8.25. We went to
the Expo. at 10.30—got
back at 4.40. Some day
we are going up Puget
Sound. I can do quite
a stunt at eating now—
devoured a small steak for
my breakfast—a dish of
strawberries, one of oatmeal,
two muffins and three
pancakes—and a cup of
coffee. Sunburn is wearing
off a trifle since I have
left the park. They have a
line of cable cars here, and
some odd big ones. The
population has increased
150,000 in 2 years.
I am getting to be
quite a critic on buildings
with two builders.

Havent done much on
the writing stunt. I
wrote Miss Childs a
steamer letter, one to
Gus, I think I wrote
one to Roswel, and a
dozen lines to Nat
telling him that I
was having a dandy
time—never knew
where I was going next
and did not know
when I'd be home;
and hoped that he'd
have as pleasant a
summer as I was
having. Found nothing
at the P.O. Gee! but
I'd like to hear. Will
probably be here until
the 20th perhaps
the 24th. Am not sure
as they don't say.
Hope you—all are well.

msContents.p: Gladys Stephens describes a multi-day visit to Yellowstone Park where she drove a coach of four horses for 3 days. She mentions her travel companions "the Virginians" and "some Germans." She describes the exhibits in the Forestry Building at the 1909 Seattle World's Fair. She describes the Forestry Building and comments that the Seattle World's Fair buildings will later be used by Seattle College. She also remarks on Seattle, which she describes as looking "new" but having a number of 12- and 14-story buildings.

div.p:
I do not know
what day we will leave
here, but we'll leave soon.
Will return to El Paso
by way of California.
Have decidedly tanned
from riding up on the
top seat with the driver
in Yellowstone Park.
I drove the coach 3
days. There were 4
horses and the coach
weighs 2400 lbs. It was
against the rules, but
the driver let me! When
we met another coach
or any soldiers the
driver took the reins.
Talk about sore arms!
And my nose, oh my
nose! It was terribly
burned, looked just
like a beet. It has
sealed now and begins
to look more respectable.

With us are some
charming Virginians
and some Germans. We
certainly have good
times. They are all
jolly.

The Exposition is fine
In the Forestry b'l'd'gbuilding
are some pretty big
"sticks." One is 74 ft long
and 4 1/2 ft sq. There is
a cross section of a tree
which is 9 ft. in diam.
There is a hollow tree
trunk which will
hold 50 peoplpeople. The
building is really
mammoth. The columns are huge
trees. I got
what I hope will be
a good picture of it.
All the b'l'd'gsbuildings are fine.
and will be used by
Seattle College later.
Every one who has
been to the other
Expositions say that
This is the best yet.
The city is large and
steadily increasing but
looks very new. There
are lots of large b'l'd'gsbuildings—
plenty of 12 stories and
several 14. There are
some dandy hotels.
Will Ma be home soon?

You had best not ans.answer
This as I will have left
before an ansanswer could
come.

div.p:
Was awfully
glad to hear from you.
Doubt if we can go to
Alaska— can't get stateroom
so many are going.
Have located the Goulds,
I telephoned today but she
was at the Expo. Got
him on the phone and I
will call later.

Mrs. Hughes (the Virginian)
is a cousin of Mrs. Dana
Gibson and Mrs. Waldorf
Astor (in England) I guess
I'll try and visit their
Uncle wants me to visit
visit them. Mrs. Jordon
(Mrs. H's cousin) has lots of
money. Her husband died
5 yrs. ago and left a large
estate. One of the sons
"blew in" $40,000 in 2 yrs.
They could buy ranch
for $12,000 and pay $25,000
for improvements. The girl
has her money too. Her
mink coat only cost $600.
I might do worse than
to visit the family don't
you think. They tried to
have me promise to visit
them.

Not much to write
about now so I guess
that I'll stop.
Now Judy dear do take
things easy.

div.p:
We arrived in Seattle
at 7:20 this morning. It was
rather rough last night, but
it was just from the wind.
It was the only rough place we
had coming back. We had a
dandy time coming back.

As a souvenir I have the
official list of the passangers
who sailed from Seattle. It
was posted by the Purser, and he gave it to me.

I'd like to know what is
the matter with auntie. I
sent her cards from Yellowstone
and some from here — among
them a leather A.Y.P.card.
I sent her some from Alaska.
also. Almost every time I
sent you one I sent her one.

I was not sick once while I
was gone. I am enough fatter
so that the people here at the
hotel spoof of it. I'm more
tanned also.

A Texasjudge who is worth
3 million was on the ship coming
back with his wife, two daughters
and 2 grandsons. He owns a ranch
in Texaswhich is about 12
miles square. They have invited
me to visit them, and Uncle
Alexwants me too. He may
have a business motive. I
will likely stop there for 2 or 3
days. He wants to take me to
a real southern hunt. I can
have a pony all for myself he
said. It is an opportunity not
to be lost, don't you agree?

We had a great time last night-
our last on board. No one turned
in before 12 some not until
2. I did at 12. It seems awfully
funny to be on land again.
They certainly were glad to see
us here at the hotel.

Well you never can tell what people will do. Waltcertainly
seems to be the limit. As for
his mother they areshe is the
limit.

So you like the Thomases?
What is that about Berenice? Do
you believe it?

I fail to see the point of Mrs.
Rich'sjoke. So the tree didn't
bloom.

I did notsend a card to
Will Ward. I sent
it to his mother !

He is a cheerful lyerlier. I
have not sent any more to the
Dotens. Do not worry. I got a
letter from Waltwhich I will
enclose. In it he acknowledges
one letter.

I did not have any hat on
while I was gone. I'm sending
a large envelope with one or
too things I do not want lost.

I got your five letters this
morning, and one from Walt,
and one from Adelaide. I'm not
sure whether Adelaide is going
to Mexico or not.

The Mexicantrip is all planned
and I start home immediately
on getting back. I'll be about
one week late. U.A.Uncle Alexhas the day
set for us to start to Mexicoand
all plans O.K.

He wants me to see all the
people whom he knows. He has
told them about my coming for
so long. I'm doing my best I
assure you. I guess I'm
succeeding fairly well. He is
so tickled he does not know
what to do. He is starting plans
for next summer already.
We are "on" for the pictures.
Heaps of love
Neddy

div.p:
It was with pleasure that
I received your Cards + letter
this P.M. but Sorry that
you did not enjoy your trip
And got Such a disagreable place
to Stop and I don't like Mr
Holland a bit for taking you
there and if your feelings at
the Depot was any thing like
mine you Certainly have my
Sympathy for dear I did not
eaveneven wait untilluntil the train pulled
out
I knowed that you were not feeling
your best So I did not tell you
the promise that I wished from
you but Asked in last letter?
And when Mr Holland asked you
if they was any tears shed
And allwaysalways remember honey I
have two Sholdersshoulders a right + also a left
one And you can have your choice
or both? by the -- way how is
our (I was going to Say little) unkleuncle
getting along better I hope?

I dare not express my feelings
in regards to the place where Holland
recommended but honey I said
Something else naughty --

I don't Care I was mad to think
of my little girl being in Such
a place If I Could only binbeen there
but dear I can never wait 2 years
before I see you I simply cant
It Seamsseems almost a year now
And the good old Santa Clara She
or he (as it is a mailmale boat) is a friend
of mine And I may Soon be back
again the Chief was down to See me
last night and he don't want me
to make this trip So I Saw the Ships
aluguelto day and he transferred me to
the North Western She he Sails
Monday #16 And he Said If he got
Any more news from Santa Clara
he would hold me over untill She he
Sails and that means $1200 per year
+ expenses I didn't mind before

But now -- Neddie
I have not binbeen over to See my mother
Since you left for the monoux She
Saw me She would want to know the
trouble And the memory of last
Voigevoyage is totoo Sweet to Share with eaveneven
my Mother as yet but I am gradually
Coming back to Earth! I only hope
I recieve your letter before I go North
again I hate to leave at all but
I must! I was very much pleased
to hear Uncle A's opinion of me
And I hope it will allwaysalways be the
Same or Improve if any thing!
"And the Small heap grows to an
Enormous Size! (this to you pet)
for I will watch every little
word for Simptomssymptoms of the heap.
improving for the better
And honey tell me all the troubles
as well as pleasures So I may share
them with you as I really feel
As I am reading your letters that
I am with you I was up town
this afternoon and Saw a few
Texas hats but not the right one
or the right face but I did not
stay long and am staying aboard
to night I have not binbeen to the fair
Since and do not think I will go again
I can saflysafely make the promise never
to Smoke cigaretts again and regards
to Drink It will be a bitter dissaperiture
that will ever Start me again it fully
makes me Shudder to think of you being
Any where near that Class in portland
And I hope you will have a better
time in San francisco!

if we only had had a little time to
ourSelves the night before on the
morning you Sailed how much
better I would have felt for I
Cannot make my Self believe
but what Something will happen
Forgive me dear if that Seamesseems
unjust but It Seamesseems totoo good to last
but will live in hopes!

Mr Jones was enquiringinquiring about today
And he told me if I heard from you
to remind you of the picture you
know which one.

well neddy the lights will be
agoing out Soon as it is nearing 10 P.M.
give my very best regards to uncle E
And Some to Mr Holland and remember
I am anxiously awaiting a reply
to last letter which is on the
road before this And I hope to
have Heaps of letters with heaps
of love on my return from
this Voigevoyage I will write again
before Sailing so you will know
how + where I am
Good ByGoodbye little girl

div.p:
Please dontdon't
feel that I have neglected
you more than others for
we have had so much on our
minds and hands for the last
few weeks that we have left
almost everyone else out.
We have a nice baby boy. A
good big baby not, not a little
teeny weeny. You know I
wished for a small baby, but
now that he is here I am glad
he is strong and perfect. If
I can only keep him well I
shall be happy. I am not very
strong yet but am gaining
every day a little, but I shall have to be
careful for awhile yet. Gladys is pleased
with her little brother and Willis is pleased
with his little son. I have only heard from
Gladys Stevens once. She was then in Colorado.
I had hoped she would keep me posetd as to
her travels. I supposed she will be home before
a great while now with many, many entertaining
things to tell you. I have thought of her very
often. Give my love to her when you see or write
her and tell her about my baby boy. You must
have missed her a very great deal. I hope you
are well. I am not able to do any house work yet.
Must not write any more this time. With love
I remain

div.p:
As I am now standing my last
watch before arriving at Juneau
and I am still a wondering
and lonesome as usual I thought
I would write a friend
which will probably be the
last chance to mail unless they
is a farther north than
which seldomeseldom happiness
It is now 1:30 a.m. as I am
still on the same 12/4 as I was
on Santa Clara and we should
arrive in Juneau about noon and
I do not know how long we will
be there and cannot say if I
can get up to see about the pictures
but will try.

As I said before Neddy dear I am writing
on watch so please excuse pencil and a
few finger marks you will I know
tell Uncle athat we have good
school teachers aboard this time and
I think he could enjoy him self
and Neddy I have found a sweet
little girl aboard and her name
is Gladys So you know she must
be Ok. She seames very fond of me
and gave me a kiss the first time I
saw her but honey the poor little
thing is only 2 years old So don't know
any better. we are having very smooth
weather so far but plenty of rain
we crossed Mill bank sound yesterday
do you remember that place I
do that so the first time
I ever had the pleasure of speaking
to you and how bad you felt I think
I could have a little more sympathy
if we ever have the pleasure of
crossing there together again
don't you honey?
which I hope will be no later than
the spring of 1910 do you? Tell me
this is the first time in a long time
that I hated to leave Seattle on account
of not being there when my letter
arrived and again when I am at sea
well I know where I am at
least. I had two letters before sailing
this time one Sunday and one Monday
at 6 p.m. from a passenger that
went north on this boat last
spring but which I did not talk
to but twice but she had a notion
or fancy but Neddie dear the
answers to both were the same
and was this—Impossible
to see you am totoo busy that's all
and the season. Neddy would not like
it and what a different feeling
comes over one when they have done
what they know to be wrightright Indeed
it is a pleasure.

you said twoto always remember and
do nothing for which your mother
would be ashamed of you.

well little girl well do I remember
the talkings I used to get as a young
fellow when going out with the boys
as it were or to a party or dance
how well do I remember in late years
how she has talked to me by the hour
to be a better boy one for a mother
to be proud of in her old age and
the last words I hear on leaving
home dear is this remember mother
prays for her boy every night do
you wonder Neddy how a boy or
man could thing to be
ashamed of "But honey I have"
but did not realize it untilluntil I met
you honey what a differene between
a mothers affections and the
one girl or the only boy which we
are bound to meet some day I do not
know if you can understand
my feelings in this or not but
please tell me will you dear please
if you only knew with what pleasure
I read your letters and watch for
any little words that will lead me
to think of heapeimproving
how I wonder what your mother
would think of me if she saw me
how I wonder what you think of
these letters of mine with us being
of quite a different desposition in
a way. Me of a very affectionate
turn of mind and you not so much
so but every thing has binbeen so
unusalunusual and out of the ordinary
that I sometimes wonder how
it all happened do you honey
be shoresure and tell me what you
think honey of these please do
I wonder if you knew how I
Uncle a two little good
night kisses which I saw him
yet But enough of this for envy
is the habit of extracting misery
from other peoples happiness.
I wonder what influence it
would have on you to have some
one put up an argument against
me for instance
passing fancy and a hundred
others but I will trust my
little girl untilluntil she tells me
diffarantedifferent than what I now believe.

You asked me if I knew the story
of the red rose "remember how dense
at times" but I can tell you the future
of one little rose if you wish
be shoresure and tell me of your trip
and how you are enjoying your self
be shoresure and ask as many questions
as you like do not be afraid honey
for I will understand.

Oh how much I would give
for one or two more nights
on Santa Clara with you now
how much could be said
and how much better we could
understand but here we are
Dear me plowing along miles
farther away every day when it
is my desire to be with you
do you know the other day well it
was after I finished reading the
first little letter I was talking to
the Chief "he calls me his boy also"
all at once he grabbed me by
the arm and shookedshook me an said
wake up boy what's the matter
can you think where my mind
was. Ms Hollinds remark does not
surprise me much honey I am getting
them now every day while
I was around the docks it was
Hellow Mack you look lonesome
this with a knowing smile.
They say absence makes theethe heart
grow fonder I do not hafhave to
worry about mine I have none
I wonder where it went it
I sent in the room honest Dear
tell me if you know please
well Neddy dear it is nearing
4 a.m. I but you are glad for I
will hafhave to close

but be shoresure and tell me all the
news from home tell me if I am
asking totoo much well
honey tell me everything
that isnt asking much is it
give my best to Uncle a
and

now I will bid you Goodnight
or rather good morning

div.p:
Have just
returned from a
birthday luncheon
and this evening
I am going out to
dinner at another
house.

It is as warm
today as a July
day at home. It
will be cool this
evening however.

I am as well as
ever.

Adelaide is
getting along
finely with her
shopping. Her
evening hat will
cost $52.95. How's that?
Everything else
accordingly.

I am wondering
what you think
of the pictures.
They were taken
in San Diego
and that dress
was all I could
wear. There was
no primping for
those pictures I
can tell you.

Got your card
yesterday.

Were you
surprised about
the pictures? We
wanted you to
be.

Here they're all
talking about
my return —and
I haven't left yet.
What do you think
of that?

Just wrote to
Pauline. Will
mail it when I
get time.
Hope you are well.
